source.e4834486: After seeing these graphs from recent years, we can denote that in kaggler population status, our underdog countries (see figure 1) are the dark purple countries such as Kenya, Morocco etc., and our underdog continents (see figure 2) are Africa.
source.a03365c9: # Why don't these countries have access to updated technology and data science?
source.d8fdc98c: # Figure 3: Countries by GDP per Capita
source.e51ef816: As compared to countries like India and United States (there are approximately 286,518,600 internet users in the US), Africa's countries have a very low internet usage.
source.02f17c93:
# **Today, the Underdogs... Tomorrow, the Challengers**
**A story of underdeveloped countries and how they can become tomorrow's challengers with data science**
![](https://media1.tenor.com/images/63dc3e50bb6f234aae79161dddbd7efd/tenor.gif?itemid=17924212)
source.7d7cdd64: # Problem 3: Lack of data science courses and research programs
source.09451199: There is not enough resources from which to learn from in Africa. There should be more webinars and events hosted in Africa related to data science to generate interest. Companies like Google and Amazon should support local colleges so they can offer up-to-date courses on data science. Many efforts need to be made for Africa to reach its full potential in data science and become a challenger of tomorrow.
source.b2cdbb6f: The "underdog" countries and continents that we identified above have a low GDP (red countries). See the below table to view a summary of our underdog countries.
source.bfe0d278: A lack of reliable, affordable electricity has caused one of the major setbacks in Africa. Without power, there is no internet. The entire digital ecosystem relies so heavily on reliable, affordable electricity, from home internet connections to the base stations that underpin cellular networks to the data centers that store the internet’s content. Demand for more Africa-based data centers is growing dramatically to serve the continent's burgeoning internet use with low-latency and high-bandwidth connectivity.
source.6d59c3ab: # Data Science: the key to success for underdeveloped countries

source.559912d4:
Data Science is all around us. Everytime we search the internet, order something on amazon, or use our fitness watches, we are using data science. Many articles talk about the plight of underdeveloped countries or the so-called underdogs. One day, I got to thinking, Could these people benefit from having acess to data science. If so, Why don't these people have acess to these resources yet? In this noteboook, I want to prove that "underdog" countries could benefit from data science, and become tomorrow's challengers, all by using the **power of data science**.
![](https://www.aircraft-commerce.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/The-Power-of-Data.jpg)
source.d5d7ad4b:
Africa is a goldmine waiting to be opened. It can rise as a challenger and key player of data science. Now, it is in the hands of projects and companies whether they realize the potential.
![](https://i.pinimg.com/originals/20/c0/27/20c0271883ddbbeda8aaa106b9c57066.gif)
Hope you saw why the underdogs of the world will grab at the chance to improve their lives and status with the **power of data science**.
source.6d97b42e: In this section, we will identify the "underdogs of the world". My hypothesis is that countries such as Kenya, Morocco and Brazil will be underdogs.
source.5510b471: Africa's data center industry is expected to grow to 600 megawatts in 2020—and just that growth alone represents a projected capital investment of more than 1 billion in the region. Notably, it is local African businesses, including Vodacom/Safaricom, MTN, Rack Center Nigeria, Africa Data Centers and Teraco that are at the forefront of this growing industry, owning more than 95 percent of data center capacity in the region. But without cheap and reliable power, data centers won't get built in Africa—wasting a tremendous economic opportunity.
